data.sampled: Yes, 10 pounds of cast iron is generally considered to be heavier than 20 pounds of flakes due to the density and weight distribution of each material. However, this does not necessarily mean that one object is actually less dense or weighs less than another just because it feels lighter. In general, when comparing two things based on their weight, it's best to look at their actual masses rather than subjective impressions of "heaviness."

data.sampled: Yes, 12 pounds of hydrogen is heavier than 10 pounds of palladium. The atomic number of hydrogen is 1 and the atomic weight of hydrogen is approximately 1 g/mol, which means that 12 pounds of hydrogen corresponds to about 6.02 x 10^23 molecules of hydrogen. On the other hand, the atomic number of palladium is 46 and its atomic weight is approximately 106 g/mol, so 10 pounds of palladium corresponds to only about 9.38 x 10^22 molecules of palladium. Therefore, there are more molecules in 12 pounds of hydrogen than in 10 pounds of palladium, making 12 pounds of hydrogen heavier than 10 pounds of palladium.

data.sampled: No, 9 pounds of soap foam is not heavier than 5 pounds of iron chains. Weight is a measure of the force with which an object is drawn toward the center of the Earth and depends on both mass (the amount of matter in an object) and gravity (the acceleration due to gravity). Soap foam has less mass per unit volume than iron chains, but it also has more buoyancy due to its low density. As a result, a given volume of soap foam will weigh less than the same volume of iron chains when they are submerged in water. However, if you were to compare two objects that have equal volumes, one made of soap foam and one made of iron chains, the one made of iron chains would be heavier because it has more mass.
